thread.title: Snowden and Miles Davis films pushed back to next year
thread.title_full: Snowden and Miles Davis films pushed back to next year

author: Bill Zwecker
title: Snowden and Miles Davis films pushed back to next year
text:
Bill Zwecker on October 12, 2015 Joseph Gordon-Levitt (left) stars as Edward Snowden in Oliver Stone's upcoming "Snowden" film. 
Two much-anticipated films — one about CIA secrets leaker Edward Snowden, and another about music legend Miles Davis — have been pushed back into 2016. 
Originally slated for a Christmas Day release, Oliver Stone’s “Snowden,” will now be coming out on May 13, according to a release from the film’s distributor, Open Road. Written by Stone and Kieran Fitzgerald, “Snowden” stars Joseph Gordon-Levitt in the title role. Other cast members include Shailene Woodley, Melissa Leo, Zachary Quinto, Tom Wilkinson, Rhys Ifans, Nicolas Cage, Scott Eastwood, Joely Richardson and Timothy Olyphant. 
The script is based on the books, “The Snowden Files: The Inside Story of the World’s Most Wanted Man” by Luke Harding; and “Time of the Octopus” by Anatoly Kucherena. 
†Meanwhile, “Miles Ahead,” starring Don Cheadle (who also co-wrote the film, directed it and plays the title role as Miles Davis) will now also not open until some time next year. Roger Friedman’s Showbiz411 website reports the movie, which recently closed the New York Film Festival, won’t even have a one-week, New York-Los Angeles release to qualify for this year’s Oscar consideration. 
The film is said to be a non-linear portrait of the music great. It is set during a two-day period in the 1980s, when Davis took a break and spent the time in a drug and liquor-induced stupor. The film also stars Michael Stuhlbarg as an unethical record producer and Ewan McGregor as a Rolling Stone reporter.
